overview: Time off work due to sickness - entitlement to Statutory Sick Pay, form SSP1, eligibility, fit notes, sick notes, recover statutory pay
title: Sick pay for your employees

table.body:
Your employees may be [eligible](/sick-leave-pay-employees "Eligibility") for Statutory Sick Pay (SSP), which is [£85.85 a week](/sick-leave-pay-employees "Entitlement") for up to 28 weeks. 

You can offer more if you have a company sick pay scheme (you can’t offer less). Company schemes are also called ‘contractual' or 'occupational' sick pay and must be included in an employment contract. 

*[SSP]: Statutory Sick Pay
table.title: Overview

table.body:
The weekly rate for Statutory Sick Pay (SSP) is £85.85 for up to 28 weeks. It is paid: 

+ for the days an employee normally works - called 'qualifying days' 
+ in the same way as wages - eg on the normal payday, deducting tax and National insurance 

##When to start paying SSP 

SSP is paid when the employee is sick for 4 days in a row (including non-working days). You start paying SSP from the fourth day (if they normally work that day).  

###Exception

You don't usually pay SSP for the first 3 qualifying days unless they've been off sick and getting SSP within the last 8 weeks. 

##When to stop paying SSP 

Usually SSP stops when the employee comes back to work or no longer [qualifies](/sick-leave-pay-employees/eligibility "Eligibility").

##Record keeping

You must keep records for HM Revenue & Customs, including:

- all sickness periods lasting at least 4 days
- your SSP payments
- any SSP you [recover](/sick-leave-pay-employees/help-with-sick-pay "Recover SSP")

You can use form SSP2 to keep these records. 

$D [Download 'Form SSP2, Statutory Sick Pay record sheet' (PDF, 135KB)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/forms/ssp2.pdf "Download 'Form SSP2, Statutory Sick Pay record sheet' (PDF, 135KB)"){:rel="external"}$D

 
*[SSP]: Statutory Sick Pay
table.title: Entitlement

table.body:
To qualify for Statutory Sick Pay (SSP) employees must:

+ be your employee - eg have a [contract of employment](/employment-contracts-and-conditions "Employment contracts")
+ have done some work under their contract 
+ have been sick for 4 or more days in a row (including non-working days) - known as a 'period of incapacity for work' 
+ earn at least £107 a week in an 8 week period 
+ give you the correct [notice](/sick-leave-pay-employees/notice-and-fit-notes "Notice")
+ give you [proof of their illness](/sick-leave-pay-employees/notice-and-fit-notes "Proof"), only after 7 days off

##Exceptions 

Employees don't get SSP if they: 

+ have received the maximum amount of SSP (28 weeks)  
+ are getting maternity, paternity or adoption pay or maternity allowance
+ are off work for a pregnancy-related illness within 4 weeks of the baby's due date 
+ have taken 3 years or more 'linked periods' of sickness - where 4 or more days of sickness happen within 8 weeks of each other
+ are working outside the EU and you’re not liable for their National Insurance Contributions 
+ are in custody on the 1st day of sickness 
+ are off work because of a trade dispute before the first day of sickness 
+ received Employment Support Allowance within 12 weeks of starting or returning to work for you

##Form SSP1

If an employee isn't eligible you must send them form SSP1 within 7 days of them going off sick. They can apply for [Employment and Support Allowance](/employment-support-allowance "Employment and Support Allowance") instead.

If your employee thinks this is unfair, they can appeal to HM Revenue and Customs. 

$D[Download 'Form SSP1, employee not entitled to SSP' (PDF, 200KB)](http://www.dwp.gov.uk/advisers/claimforms/ssp1.pdf "Download 'Form SSP1, employee not entitled to SSP' (PDF, 200KB)"){:rel="external"}  
[Download 'Form SSP1 - Northern Ireland, employee not entitled to SSP' (PDF, 200KB)](http://www.dsdni.gov.uk/ssp1_cp.pdf "Download 'Form SSP1 - Northern Ireland, employee not entitled to SSP' (PDF, 200KB)"){:rel="external"}
$D

##Long-term illness 

If you know an employee will be off for more than 28 weeks, you can complete SSP1 in advance. This means they can apply for Employment Support Allowance without delay. 

*[SSP]: Statutory Sick Pay
table.title: Eligibility

table.body:
##Notice 

The employee should tell you they're sick within your own time limit (or 7 days if you don’t have one). You don't have to pay Statutory Sick Pay if they don't meet these time limits. 

You can't insist notice is given in person or on a special form. 

##Asking for proof 

After 7 days off sick you can ask the employee for a [fit note](/taking-sick-leave "Fit notes") from their doctor. This used to be called a sick note. 

You can't withhold SSP if the employee is late sending you a fit note. 

*[SSP]: Statutory Sick Pay
table.title: Notice and fit notes

table.body:
##Recover Statutory Sick Pay 

You may be able to [recover the statutory payments](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/paye/employees/statutory-pay/ssp-calc.htm "Recover Statutory Sick Pay"){:rel="external"} you've paid from HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC). Your payroll software or [HMRC's Basic PAYE Tools](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/paye/tools/basic-paye-tools.htm "HMRC Basic PAYE tools"){:rel="external"} can tell you how much you'll get back. 

##If you can't afford to pay SSP 

You can apply for an [advance payment from HMRC](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/paye/employees/statutory-pay/funding.htm "Statutory payment help from HMRC"){:rel="external"} if you can't afford to pay SSP. 

*[SSP]: Statutory Sick Pay
*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
